fields.summary: Hitting walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb limit creates orphan files on the WS file system

fields.summary: Cannot upload to walrus: entity too large

comments.body: The above is reproducible every time. We cannot upload any backup at the moment.
Where can I see this behaviour at ? Internal machine ?
moving to confirmed so tracked properly
Attaching now the output of euca-describe-properties, the list of files in the bucket, and what walrus reports.

I can't get s3curl-euca to work in a centos instance : {noformat} [root@lists ~]# /usr/bin/s3curl-euca.pl --id community --put //tmp/archive.tgz -- -v http://10.101.1.13:8773/services/Walrus/mailman/mailman-archive.tgz-day_of_month * About to connect() to 10.101.1.13 port 8773 (#0) * Trying 10.101.1.13... connected * Connected to 10.101.1.13 (10.101.1.13) port 8773 (#0) > PUT /services/Walrus/mailman/mailman-archive.tgz-day_of_month HTTP/1.1 > User-Agent: curl/7.19.7 (x86_64-redhat-linux-gnu) libcurl/7.19.7 NSS/3.13.1.0 zlib/1.2.3 libidn/1.18 libssh2/1.2.2 > Host: 10.101.1.13:8773 > Accept: */* > Date: Wed, 20 Feb 2013 09:36:58 +0000 > Authorization: AWS VGSBKGOCB8ONKEGDNRHDB:j5ScFa0L3zWr1EDKPWJ2RXOHWEc= > Content-Length: 6248 > Expect: 100-continue > * Done waiting for 100-continue < HTTP/1.1 403 Forbidden < Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8 * no chunk, no close, no size. Assume close to signal end < 403 ForbiddenUnable to parse date.com.eucalyptus.auth.login.AuthenticationException: Unable to parse date. com.eucalyptus.auth.login.AuthenticationException: Unable to parse date. at com.eucalyptus.ws.handlers.WalrusAuthenticationHandler.handle(WalrusAuthenticationHandler.java:251) {noformat} However the same procedure works from my admin account ( ran from the CLC) There appears to be a accounting error someone on the walrus server because the buckets do not exceed limit specified by: PROPERTY walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb 5120

It appears  you are running some of these curl uploads as a admin account (privilege ), the accounting limits are not honored ; that explains why statistics reported by examining the /var/<buckket>/mailman using "du -sh " are larger than property
 " storagemaxbucketsizeinmb "

if you updating files using curl put  as a non-admin account ; these limits are enforced.
Not to the best of my knowledge. The user I have been using is the 'community' user, with no special privileges.
To be precises, it is the 'admin' user under the 'community' account. No 'eucalyptus' account were used in this ticket.
Any user under eucalyptus is an admin. You need to create a new account.

1. created a account: account01 . 2. created a user : fred 3. created a group : fredgroup added fred to fredgroup, fredgroup to account01. ( all in GUI console ) I can view this account setup with the cli ? 4. euca-conf -get-creds -a account01 -u fred fredcreds.zip 5. euca-add-group -d "fred security group" fredsecgroup euca-authorize -p 25 -P tcp -s 0.0.0.0/0 fredsecgroup euca-authorize -p 22 -P tcp -s 0.0.0.0/0 fredsecgroup Create a bucket using eucalyptus:admin {noformat} /usr/bin/s3curl-euca.pl --id community --createBucket -- http://10.101.1.13:8773/services/Walrus/fredbucket fredbucket[root@b-13 bukkits]# {noformat} 6. modify mailman.sh to use fred's EC2 creds and http://10.101.1.13:8773/services/Walrus/fredbucket run-instance -g fredsecgroup -k fredkeys -f fred.sh {noformat} 7. /usr/bin/s3curl-euca.pl --id community --put user-data.out -- http://10.101.1.13:8773/services/Walrus/fredbucket/poo AccessDeniedAccess Deniedfredbucketfa0ac86d-7ee2-484c-8d4a-3a448b88219a {noformat}

I got the logs from the production cloud: 

{noformat}
********************************************************************************
Message               : Component that caused exception is: Bukkit. Message payload is of type: PutObjectType
Type                  : org.mule.api.service.ServiceException
Code                  : MULE_ERROR--2
Payload               : <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<euca:PutObjectType xmlns:euca="http://msgs.eucalyptus.com">
  <euca:WalrusDataRequestType>
    <euca:WalrusRequestType>
      <euca:correlationId>e499ba67-29bd-4c26-8b2c-f33355f4f038</euca:correlationId>
      <euca:_return>true</euca:_return>
      <euca:_services/>
      <euca:_disabledServices/>
      <euca:_notreadyServices/>

      <euca:bucket>mailman</euca:bucket>
      <euca:key>mailman-archive.tgz-22</euca:key>
    </euca:WalrusRequestType>
    <euca:randomKey>mailman.mailman-archive.tgz-22.nTQG2JyIsM2m9g..</euca:randomKey>
  </euca:WalrusDataRequestType>
  <euca:contentLength>26019040</euca:contentLength>
  <euca:metaData/>

</euca:PutObjectType>

********************************************************************************
Exception stack is:
1. Your proposed upload exceeds the maximum allowed object size. (edu.ucsb.eucalyptus.cloud.EntityTooLargeException)
  edu.ucsb.eucalyptus.cloud.ws.WalrusManager:1171 (null)
2. Component that caused exception is: Bukkit. Message payload is of type: PutObjectType (org.mule.api.service.ServiceException)
  org.mule.component.DefaultLifecycleAdapter:214 (http://mule.mulesource.org/docs/apidocs/org/mule/api/service/ServiceException.html)
Root Exception stack trace:
edu.ucsb.eucalyptus.cloud.EntityTooLargeException: Your proposed upload exceeds the maximum allowed object size.
        at edu.ucsb.eucalyptus.cloud.ws.WalrusManager.incrementBucketSize(WalrusManager.java:1171)
        at edu.ucsb.eucalyptus.cloud.ws.WalrusManager.putObject(WalrusManager.java:1023)
        at edu.ucsb.eucalyptus.cloud.ws.WalrusControl.PutObject(WalrusControl.java:288)
        at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor422.invoke(Unknown Source)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:616)
        at org.mule.model.resolvers.AbstractEntryPointResolver.invokeMethod(AbstractEntryPointResolver.java:147)
        at org.mule.model.resolvers.ReflectionEntryPointResolver.invoke(ReflectionEntryPointResolver.java:127)
        at org.mule.model.resolvers.DefaultEntryPointResolverSet.invoke(DefaultEntryPointResolverSet.java:50)
        at org.mule.component.DefaultLifecycleAdapter.intercept(DefaultLifecycleAdapter.java:202)
        at org.mule.component.AbstractJavaComponent.invokeComponentInstance(AbstractJavaComponent.java:82)
        at org.mule.component.AbstractJavaComponent.doOnCall(AbstractJavaComponent.java:73)
        at org.mule.component.AbstractComponent.onCall(AbstractComponent.java:87)

        at org.mule.work.WorkerContext.run(WorkerContext.java:310)

Confirmed:

This behavior appears as a non-eucalyptus account since 
"storagemaxbucketsizeinmb " is only enforced in that mode. 

The issue is that reporting is not accurate :   listing the 
bucket via scurl  is not the same as the what is actually 
in the bucket.


{noformat}

root@lists:~# /usr/bin/s3curl-euca.pl --id community -- -s  http://173.205.188.6:8773/services/Walrus/mailman|xmlindent|grep Key
    <MaxKeys>1000</MaxKeys><IsTruncated>false</IsTruncated>
        <Key>aliases</Key><LastModified>2013-02-02T18:30:10.000Z</LastModified><ETag>e14bd3b44169ae2a998b5624c3c15e75</ETag><Size>5425</Size>
        <Key>lists</Key><LastModified>2013-02-02T18:30:13.000Z</LastModified><ETag>589c326433ef4c49e7f54d00f44b7af8</ETag><Size>2558</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz</Key><LastModified>2013-02-02T18:30:09.000Z</LastModified><ETag>5983cca602b8aafa2b111fc22c9acd54</ETag><Size>24657766</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-01</Key><LastModified>2013-02-01T23:30:08.000Z</LastModified><ETag>b7f80aa6cbb4b9748e57690249eea37a</ETag><Size>24630481</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-02</Key><LastModified>2013-02-02T18:30:08.000Z</LastModified><ETag>5983cca602b8aafa2b111fc22c9acd54</ETag><Size>24657766</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-03</Key><LastModified>2013-01-29T02:34:13.000Z</LastModified><ETag>4d3d6271884dc1a9b965951eeb088041</ETag><Size>23326732</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-15</Key><LastModified>2013-02-15T19:55:21.000Z</LastModified><ETag>d8e8fca2dc0f896fd7cb4cb0031ba249</ETag><Size>5</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-29</Key><LastModified>2013-01-29T23:30:07.000Z</LastModified><ETag>cd2028a2df520913b84e477fa994f6dc</ETag><Size>23449970</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-30</Key><LastModified>2013-01-30T23:30:08.000Z</LastModified><ETag>9c20bf44df0358ad406895bc10d418e9</ETag><Size>24244340</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-31</Key><LastModified>2013-01-31T23:30:08.000Z</LastModified><ETag>4ce71672bcfeb5e9c972a57346f5d27d</ETag><Size>24399819</Size>
        <Key>pippo</Key><LastModified>2013-02-05T20:24:32.000Z</LastModified><ETag>d87176bfa1e0c5d347ba776403774a5b</ETag><Size>297</Size>
root@lists:~# 

{noformat}


{noformat}

/usr/bin/s3curl-euca.pl --id community -- -s  http://173.205.188.6:8773/services/Walrus/mailman|xmlindent|grep Key | cut -d\> -f 8 | cut -d\< -f1 | awk '{ sum+=$1} END {print sum}'
169375159

169MB 

{noformat}


Contents of bucket on walrus:


{noformat}

 ls -la /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits/mailman/ | awk '{ sum+=$5} END {print sum}'
7423361800

 7.4GB 


{noformat}
Quotas are not enforced for the admin user. But that is unrelated to the mismatch between what is on disk and what Walrus believes (that is in the DB).

If there is an inconsistency in accounting for the bucket then it will be reflected in the db, not the contents of the by /var/eucalyptus directory as reported by ls ; so we could essentially have an accounting issue ( in size) with the contents of buckets ;

I proved that the limits work; 



{noformat}

1. created a user policy:

euare-grouplistpolicies -g fredSecgroup -p fredbucketUP  -v
{
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Action": "s3:*",
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Resource": "*"
    }
  ]
}


2.  added  account01/fred to policy 
 
 euare-grouplistusers -g fredSecgroup

        arn:aws:iam::account01:group/fredSecgroup
	users
	arn:aws:iam::account01:user/fred

3.   Created a instance using fred's credentials 
  
euca-run-instances -g mailman  -k fredcred  emi-9FBB38EA  -f fred.sh

4.   Credentials of s3curl match fred's eucarc cred:

[root@lists ~]# cat .s3curl 
%awsSecretAccessKeys = (
	community => {
		url => '10.101.1.13',
		id => 'SJRECKMGV1A56QIEXERTJ',
		key => 'ffHHJdft57lJ52hPNlQplRWDb71Olafa2fqILgtn',
	},
);


{noformat}

From this point I can upload files from the instance
and control the size by

{noformat}

euca-modify-property -p walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb=100

{noformat}


Once the limit is reached, bucket uploads are no longer permitted
by the non-eucal user,  but a eucalyptus user can upload / delete files 
to the same bucket without limits,
and those uploads are seen from the non-eucal user account:

{noformat}
cat sum.sh 
/usr/bin/s3curl-euca.pl --id community -- -s  http://10.101.1.13:8773/services/Walrus/fredbucket2/ | xmlindent|grep Key | cut -d\> -f 8 | cut -d\< -f1 | awk ' { sum+=$1} END {print sum}'
[root@lists ~]# 


{noformat}


{noformat}

1. Current bucket size as seen by the non-eucal user:

./sum.sh
225046111


2. upload a file to the same bucket from a eucal-user :

[root@lists ~]# ./sum.sh
243865854

3. List new file : ( mailman-archive.tgz-06a ) as seen by non-eucal-user: 

[root@lists ~]# /usr/bin/s3curl-euca.pl --id community -- -s  http://10.101.1.13:8773/services/Walrus/fredbucket2/ | xmlindent|grep Key
    <MaxKeys>1000</MaxKeys><IsTruncated>false</IsTruncated>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz</Key><LastModified>2013-03-06T18:20:32.000Z</LastModified><ETag>2049cea39507d45458c96ae68694a122</ETag><Size>18819743</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-06</Key><LastModified>2013-03-06T18:38:43.000Z</LastModified><ETag>6467809e1aa8a37d362498c967c887ee</ETag><Size>187406625</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-06a</Key><LastModified>2013-03-06T20:06:27.000Z</LastModified><ETag>377179cd6b858af746bd94811f872241</ETag><Size>18819743</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-day_of_month</Key><LastModified>2013-03-06T18:10:43.000Z</LastModified><ETag>d96c24ad984672d8a81740dcd2bf3d8d</ETag><Size>18819743</Size>

4. delete file  ( file 06a) using the eucal-user, and observe it disappears from the 
    non-eucal user :


[root@lists ~]# /usr/bin/s3curl-euca.pl --id community -- -s  http://10.101.1.13:8773/services/Walrus/fredbucket2/ | xmlindent|grep Key
    <MaxKeys>1000</MaxKeys><IsTruncated>false</IsTruncated>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz</Key><LastModified>2013-03-06T18:20:32.000Z</LastModified><ETag>2049cea39507d45458c96ae68694a122</ETag><Size>18819743</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-06</Key><LastModified>2013-03-06T18:38:43.000Z</LastModified><ETag>6467809e1aa8a37d362498c967c887ee</ETag><Size>187406625</Size>
        <Key>mailman-archive.tgz-day_of_month</Key><LastModified>2013-03-06T18:10:43.000Z</LastModified><ETag>d96c24ad984672d8a81740dcd2bf3d8d</ETag><Size>18819743</Size>

5.  bucket size reduced from non-eucal user view: 

./sum.sh 

225046111


{noformat}

I ran tests that uploaded and deleted files ( in a loop)
to a shared bucket ( one upload  using a VM running as a non-eucal user 
and other as eucal-user ) without seeing any abnormal
bucket accounting. 

The files created by eucal-user can be listed by the non-eucal user, 
and even deleted with the 
policy defined. 

I can't reproduce this issue  on 3.2.2. ;
Can't reproduce the behavior on 3.2.2.
Cool, that's good news.

Well - This was fixed in 3.2 ! 

 https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-2275
Fixed in 3.2
Fixed in 3.2
Confirmed fixed in 3.2 .
Do you know which commit corresponds to the fix in 3.2?
https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-2275
